case_vignette: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 4-day history of painful lesions in his mouth. During the past year, he has twice had similar lesions that resolved without treatment after approximately 10 days. He has never had any genital or anal lesions. His mother reports that he has been very stressed over the past month because he is approaching his senior year at high school. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. He appears thin. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F). A photograph of his oral cavity is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have painful sores in my mouth for the past 4 days.
Thank you for sharing that information. Can you tell me, are the sores located on your lips, tongue, or inside of your cheeks?
The sores are inside my mouth.

No, I haven't experienced fatigue, weight loss, or night sweats.
Okay, that's good to know. Based on what you've told me, I would like to perform a quick examination of your mouth to get a better look at the sores. Can you open wide please and say "ahh"?

Great, thank you. Based on what I see, I would like to take some additional information to help determine the cause of the sores. Can you tell me if you have noticed any changes in your diet or eating habits recently?
No, there haven't been any changes in my diet or eating habits.

Okay, that's good to know. Based on what you've told me, I would like to perform a few more tests to help determine the cause of the sores. Can you please rinse your mouth with water and spit it out? And then, can you open your mouth again so I can take a closer look at the sores?

Great, thank you. After examining the sores again, I would like to take some additional tests to help determine the cause. Can you please provide a saliva sample for me to test? And also, can you tell me if you have any history of dental work or any dental problems?
I can provide a saliva sample, and I haven't had any dental work or problems.

Great, thank you for providing the saliva sample. Based on the results of the tests we've performed so far, I would like to refer you to a specialist for further evaluation and treatment.

It's possible that the sores in your mouth are related to an underlying autoimmune disorder, such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis. The specialist will be able to perform more detailed tests and examinations to determine the exact cause of the sores and develop an appropriate treatment plan.

In the meantime, there are some things you can do to help manage your symptoms. You can try using a saltwater rinse to help reduce the inflammation and promote healing. Mix 1/2 teaspoon of salt with 8 ounces of warm water and swish it around your mouth for 30 seconds before spitting it out.

You can also try taking over-the-counter pain medication, such as ibuprofen or acetaminophen, to help reduce any discomfort or pain. Just be sure to follow the instructions on the label and talk to your doctor or pharmac
